projectDesc.p: "定風波慢" is part of The Global Medieval Sourcebook, a digital compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. This larger project comprises computer-readable transcriptions and/or editions of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century, and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia; accompanied by new English translations; high-resolution digital images of manuscript/early print sources, where available; an apparatus that includes critical introductions, textual notes and annotations; and a flexible user interface with which to navigate these materials.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.rdg: To the Tune “Still Wind and Waves, Long Song”
Since the spring comes,
I am saddened by the green and dejected by the red.
My heart cares about nothing.
The sun ascends the flowery branch,
oriels fly through the willow twigs;
I am still lying under the fragrant quilt.
My warm and soft body wastes away;
my shiny cloud-like hair droops down.
Listless all day, I am tired of dressing up.
What can I do,
I resent that ever since the fickle one left,
there is not a single message from him.
If only I knew (it would be like this).
I regret back then,
that I did not lock away his carved saddle,
facing the window of his study,
giving him solely foreign paper and ivory brush,
restrain him and ask him to chant and recite.
I should have been with him all day,
not letting him avoid me.
With needles and threads, sitting by him.
Allow me,
so that I will not let youth
go past vainly.
